May 13, 2001: Fiction
ON THE STREET WHERE YOU LIVE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$26.) A defense lawyer finds herself haunted by two murders that took place 110
years apart.
A COMMON LIFE, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $24.95.) Celebrating the wedding of
Father Tim Kavanagh and Cynthia Coppersmith; the sixth book in the "Mitford
Years" series.
LONE EAGLE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) A woman is reunited with
the love of her life, a legendary aviator who was Charles Lindbergh's protégé.
DREAMCATCHER, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) In the woods of Maine, four
hunters who have been friends since boyhood encounter a disoriented stranger
and a dangerous creature from another world.
1ST TO DIE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) Four women -- a
homicide inspector, a medical examiner, an assistant district attorney and a
journalist -- search for a killer who is stalking newlyweds.
A PAINTED HOUSE, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The experiences of
a 7-year-old boy whose parents live and work in the cotton fields of Arkansas.
DEATH IN HOLY ORDERS, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $25.) Cmdr. Adam Dalgliesh
investigates the death of a powerful businessman's son at a small theological
college in England.
COLD PARADISE, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $24.95.) The lawyer and
investigator Stone Barrington travels to Palm Beach to help a beautiful woman.
HEART OF A WARRIOR, by Johanna Lindsey. (Morrow, $25.) A California
woman falls for a strikingly handsome Nordic man who is nearly seven feet tall.
THE LAST TIME THEY MET, by Anita Shreve. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Two writers
who once had a passionate affair meet years later at a literary festival.
THE BONESETTER'S DAUGHTER, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $25.95.) A Chinese-
American woman struggles to understand her family and herself.
THE VILLA, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $25.95.) A businesswoman is torn
between her professional rivalry with a vintner and her strong attraction to him.
SCARLET FEATHER, by Maeve Binchy. (Dutton, $25.95.) Tom Feather and
Cathy Scarlet, friends from cooking school, start a catering company in Dublin.
THE SKIES OF PERN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.) Danger
threatens the beautiful world of Pern; the 13th book in a fantasy series.
Non-Fiction
SEABISCUIT, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of the
horse whose career culminated in a 1938 match race with War Admiral.
NAPALM & SILLY PUTTY, by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $22.95.) The comedian
offers opinions on everything from God to pets to the Lone Ranger's laundry.
FOUNDING BROTHERS, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf, $26.) A historian's study of
the intertwined lives of the nation's founders.
IN HARM'S WAY, by Doug Stanton. (Holt, $25.) The sinking of the cruiser
Indianapolis in World War II and the story of its survivors.
A DIFFERENT DRUMMER, by Michael K. Deaver. (HarperCollins, $25.) A former
aide and long time friend recalls his three decades with Ronald Reagan.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
ABSOLUTE POWER, by David Limbaugh. (Regnery, $27.95.) A lawyer's critical
evaluation of the Clinton-Reno Justice Department.
FAST FOOD NATION, by Eric Schlosser. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A survey of "the
dark side of the all-American meal."
BODY OF SECRETS, by James Bamford. (Doubleday, $29.95.) An investigative
reporter goes inside the National Security Agency and the world of electronic
spying.
AMERICAN TERRORIST, by Lou Michel and Dan Herbeck. (ReganBooks/ Harper
Collins, $26.) Two reporters examine the Oklahoma City bombing and the life of
Timothy McVeigh.
WALKING THE BIBLE, by Bruce Feiler. (Morrow, $26.) A 10,000-mile journey
retracing the story told in the Pentateuch.
COMFORT ME WITH APPLES, by Ruth Reichl. (Random House, $24.95.) The
second volume of memoirs by the former restaurant critic for The New York
Times.
STOLEN LIVES, by Malika Oufkir and Michele Fitoussi. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion,
$24.) A Moroccan woman recalls the 20 years she spent in a desert jail.
FINDING FISH, by Antwone Quenton Fisher with Mim Eichler Rivas. (Morrow,
$25.) From life in foster homes to experiences in the Navy to success in
Hollywood: a memoir.
